dt: {bc}the study of the general principles of scientific classification {bc}{sx|systematics||}
{bc}orderly classification of plants and animals according to their presumed natural relationships

et: borrowed from French {it}taxonomie,{/it} from Greek {it}táxis{/it} "arrangement, order" + French {it}-o-{/it} {et_link|-o-|-o-} + {it}-nomie{/it} {et_link|-nomy|-nomy} {ma}{mat|taxis|}{/ma}

French {it}taxonomie{/it} was a coinage of the Geneva-born botanist Augustin Pyramus de Candolle (1778-1841), in {it}Théorie élémentaire de la botanique{/it} (Paris, 1813). Candolle divided botany into three divisions (p. 19): "… elle se compose 1.{sup}o{/sup} de la {it}Glossologie,{/it} c'est-à-dire, de la connaissance des termes par lesquels on designe les organes des plantes et leurs diverses modification; 2.{sup}o{/sup} de la {it}Taxonomie{/it} [footnote: "Mot formé de ταξις ordre, et νόμος loi, règle."], ou de la Théorie des classifications appliquée au règne végétal; 3.{sup}o{/sup} de la {it}Phytographie,{/it} ou de l'art de décrire les plantes de la manière la plus utile aux progrès de la science …" ("… it is composed of 1.{sup}o{/sup} {it}Glossology,{/it} that is, the recognition of the terms by which the organs of plants are designated, and their various modifications; ; 2.{sup}o{/sup} {it}Taxonomy{/it} [footnote: "Word formed from {it}táxis{/it} order, and {it}nómos{/it} law, rule."], or the theory of classifications applied to the vegetable kingdom; 3.{sup}o{/sup} {it}Phytography,{/it} or the art of describing plants in the manner most suited to the progress of science"). A more correct compounding form in terms of Greek word formation would have been {it}taxi-{/it} (as {it}táxis{/it} is an i-stem), and {it}taxinomy{/it} did in fact see some use in the 19th century—though Candolle's original coinage has predominated. His parallel introductions, {it}glossology{/it} and {it}phytography,{/it} have rarely been employed.

classification; especially : orderly classification of plants and animals according to their presumed natural relationships
